title: Atheists file lawsuit to officiate marriage
content: GRAND RAPIDS, MI (WOOD/CNN) - The Center for Inquiry is a national organization that advocates for a secular society with an office in metro Grand Rapids, MI.  "We have an organized system of beliefs that's called 'secular humanism,'" said Jennifer Beahan the center’s executive director.  The group is suing the Kent County Clerk's Office on behalf of all of Michigan saying its trained members should be allowed to officiate weddings.  "You know how important weddings are to people and to families," Beahan said. "It's a major life event and secular individuals should be able to celebrate that in a way that they want that's most memorable and meaningful to them."  While people who don't want to have a religious wedding can head to city hall or the courthouse, this group says that is still hardly equal.  "You have to do it on their schedule. They provide you a copy of the vows that they read for you and you don't get to have it at the place of your time and choosing. You don't get to personalize it," she said.  Some people also get ordinations offered by groups like Quaker-affiliated Humanist Society, the Universal Life Church or more farcical organizations like Church of The Flying Spaghetti Monster or The Church of The Latter-Day Dude inspired by the movie ‘The Big Lewbowski.’  "I've sat through day-long training and have to do an annual re-certification. But that's a loophole, I shouldn't have to do that because it's basically saying that I have to play act that I'm religious," Beahan said.  The group said they talked to legislators in Michigan many of whom agreed with them but feared the political blow-back if they were to introduce such a measure. The center then followed with the lawsuit.  The group has had success in other states like Indiana where the courts sided with them after a fight by the attorney general there who said that allowing just anyone to perform marriage would diminish what many hold to be a sacrament.  "You can't say theirs is special because that's a special right, and we're guaranteed that freedom of religion and freedom from religion in the Constitution," Beahan said.
